thread.title: Daughter separated from her family in Iran reunites with them at Logan
thread.title_full: Daughter separated from her family in Iran reunites with them at Logan - The Boston Globe

author: bostonglobe
title: Daughter separated from her family in Iran reunites with them at Logan
text:
Google+
Aram Boghosian for The Boston Globe
Ali Reza Jalili (left) greeted his niece Helia Jalili at Logan Airport on Saturday.
By Felicia Gans Globe Correspondent February 06, 2017
Hamid Reza Jalili waited nervously beside his brother, wife, and seventh-grade daughter at Logan Airport Sunday, hoping his older daughter would walk through the international arrival doors.
He watched as other families were reunited — mothers and children, husbands and wives.
Advertisement
But 19-year-old Helia Jalili was still somewhere behind those doors. She had been turned away Saturday at the airport in their native Iran when the family started their journey to Boston together but told her parents and sister to go on without her.
When the three arrived at Logan Saturday afternoon, Hamid Reza Jalili told a reporter he was glad but missed Helia.
Get Fast Forward in your inbox: Forget yesterday's news. Get what you need today in this early-morning email. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters here “I am happy, but my happiness is not complete,” he said at the time. “If she can come here tomorrow, my happiness will be complete.”
View Story After Trump’s travel ban, six days in limbo For 13 years, Hamid Reza Jalili waited to get a visa so he could move to the US. Then Donald Trump became president.
Seattle judge halts Trump’s order Logan: The site of many reunions DOJ asks court to stay order
The family’s last communication with her was a text message at about 4 a.m. Sunday, while she waited to board a Boston-bound Lufthansa flight in Frankfurt. The family never heard whether she got on the plane, but they hoped the lull in communication was a good indication that she had.
Then, just before 3 p.m., Helia Jalili walked out from the arrival doors at Logan, and her father’s anxious face broadened into a smile. Her mother, Baharehsadat Khamesi, and younger sister, Haniya Jalili, ran to hug her.
Advertisement
“We were nervous, all of us,” Hamid Reza Jalili said. “In all our life, we didn’t have this bad experience.”
Helia Jalili’s arrival came in Boston came after a wrenching week for her family, who had been trapped in Tehran for a week, casualties of President’s Trump’s travel ban, after they first tried to leave Jan. 29, but were barred.
Helia Jalili, an aspiring veterinarian, said when she arrived at the airport again Saturday in Tehran with her parents, she was not given a reason why she couldn’t travel to the United States. They said her name had been e-mailed to the gate officials as someone not to be allowed on the plane.
Even Sunday, she had no further explanation. But her second attempt at flying to Boston went smoothly, without any hurdles, she said.
“It wasn’t as bad as I thought,” she said, as her dad FaceTimed with his mother, who lives in New Hampshire. The teen briefly turned to the phone to say hello to her grandmother.
Helia Jalili said she was relieved to be back with her family and excited to continue her veterinary studies in the United States. She said she was thankful for the support she had received this weekend, and said that even an Iranian airport employee was excited to learn she would be able to meet her family in Boston.
“The Iranian man in the airport recognized me and told me he’s happy I can go,” she said, “and ‘Tell your parents ‘hi.’ ’”

Felicia Gans can be reached at felicia.gans@globe.com .
